question: what are people saying about generative AI, what is the latest breaking news on it

highlights: One of our questions sought their prediction of where the next bubble would be, and almost half of those surveyed mentioned generative AI. While several investors said they were bullish on the new tech overall, they also admitted that the sector was likely to get lost in its own hype. Don Butler, managing director at Thomvest Ventures, feels the bubble is already here.

Don Butler, managing director at Thomvest Ventures, feels the bubble is already here. “We believe that the applicability of AI to so many use cases will lead to a very large number of startups being funded in the space, including at some eye-watering valuations, and so we think that the next big bubble is already expanding in this area,” he said. This isn’t surprising, given how the sector has burgeoned recently as consumer tools like ChatGPT, DALL-E and Lensa AI soared in popularity both in and outside the tech community.
summaries.summary: Venture capitalists, after the crypto craze of 2021, are now eyeing generative AI as the next big investment bubble. A TechCrunch survey of over 35 investors revealed nearly half predict generative AI to be the next bubble, despite overall bullish sentiments. The sector's rapid growth, fueled by popular tools like ChatGPT, DALL-E, and Lensa AI, has led to a surge in startups receiving funding at high valuations. Thomvest Ventures' Don Butler acknowledges the bubble's presence, attributing it to AI's broad applicability and the consequent influx of funded startups, some at staggering valuations.

highlights: “a sketch of a bird perched on a windowsill”) as they work their way through massive training datasets. The models are trained to “re-create” images as opposed to drawing them from scratch, starting with pure noise and refining the image over time to make it incrementally closer to the text prompt. Perfect recreations don’t occur often, to Torres’ point.

The models are trained to “re-create” images as opposed to drawing them from scratch, starting with pure noise and refining the image over time to make it incrementally closer to the text prompt. Perfect recreations don’t occur often, to Torres’ point. As for images in the style of a particular artist, style has proven nearly impossible to shield with copyright.
summaries.summary: Generative AI's integration into mainstream technology has sparked numerous lawsuits against major companies like Microsoft, GitHub, OpenAI, Midjourney, and Stability AI for alleged copyright violations. These companies are accused of training their AI systems on copyrighted content without permission, leading to the replication of licensed code snippets, art, and images. For instance, Getty Images sued Stability AI for using its images to train Stable Diffusion without authorization. The legal challenges highlight the AI's tendency to reproduce copyrighted material from its training data, raising concerns over copyright infringement. Despite these legal battles, the generative AI sector continues to grow, with $1.3 billion raised in venture funding through November 2022. However, the lawsuits have prompted some platforms to ban AI-generated content and have sparked debates over the legality and ethics of using copyrighted works to train AI models. Legal experts predict a surge in litigation and emphasize the need for clearer copyright laws to address the unique challenges posed by generative AI.

highlights: Taxes may apply. Offer terms are subject to change.   Subscribe to The Times to read (and print) as many articles as you’d like.
Cancellation takes effect at the end of your current billing period. Taxes may apply. Offer terms are subject to change.
summaries.summary: The New York Times is offering a digital subscription at an introductory rate of $4 every 4 weeks for the first year, after which the rate increases to $17 every 4 weeks. This offer is not available to current subscribers and excludes access to NYT Games, Cooking, Wirecutter, and The Athletic. The subscription automatically renews and can be canceled at the end of the billing period. The offer excludes the print edition and is subject to change, with taxes potentially applicable. Subscribers can access unlimited articles online.

highlights: The start-up has held discussions about a large round of funding, according to three people with knowledge of the situation. Replika, another chatbot company, and You.com, which is rolling out similar technology into a new kind of search engine, said they, too, had received unsolicited interest from investors. All specialize in generative A.I.

Replika, another chatbot company, and You.com, which is rolling out similar technology into a new kind of search engine, said they, too, had received unsolicited interest from investors. All specialize in generative A.I. The result of more than a decade of research inside companies like OpenAI, these technologies are poised to remake everything from online search engines like Google Search and Microsoft Bing to photo and graphics editors like Photoshop.
summaries.summary: Anthropic, a San Francisco-based AI startup focusing on generative artificial intelligence, is nearing a deal to raise approximately $300 million in new funding, potentially valuing the company at around $5 billion. Founded in 2021, Anthropic has previously secured $704 million, with a significant portion from Sam Bankman-Fried and FTX, now facing bankruptcy and fraud charges. This funding surge reflects Silicon Valley's intense interest in generative AI technologies, capable of producing text, images, and media from simple prompts. Amid a broader tech investment slowdown, generative AI startups like Anthropic, Character.AI, Replika, and You.com are attracting significant investor attention, underscoring the sector's growth potential despite unclear profitability paths.

highlights: system, GPT-3, which could generate text on its own, including tweets, blog posts, news articles and even computer code. Last year, it unveiled DALL-E, which lets anyone generate photorealistic images simply by describing what he or she wants to see. Based on the same technology as GPT-3, ChatGPT showed the general public just how powerful this kind of technology could be.

More than a million people tested the chatbot during its first few days online, using it to answer trivia questions, explain ideas and generate everything from poetry to term papers. Microsoft has already incorporated GPT-3, DALL-E and other OpenAI technologies into its products. Most notably, GitHub, a popular online service for programmers owned by Microsoft, offers Copilot, a tool that can automatically generate snippets of computer code.
summaries.summary: Microsoft has significantly deepened its commitment to generative AI by announcing a "multiyear, multibillion-dollar" investment in OpenAI, the creators of ChatGPT. Although the exact amount wasn't disclosed, sources suggest Microsoft is investing $10 billion, building on a previous investment exceeding $3 billion. This partnership aims to keep Microsoft competitive against tech giants like Google, Meta, and Apple by leveraging OpenAI's advanced AI technologies, including text and image generation. The collaboration will focus on delivering cutting-edge AI tools and infrastructure to developers and organizations. This move comes amidst Microsoft's broader organizational restructuring, including a reduction of 10,000 positions, emphasizing a strategic pivot towards AI as a core area of growth. OpenAI, transitioning from a nonprofit to a for-profit entity to secure necessary funding, continues to push the boundaries of AI with innovations like GPT-3 and DALL-E. highlights: That, by the way, is the result of asking it to make music that would play at a gym. You may also have noticed that the lyrics are nonsense, but in a way that you may not necessarily catch if you’re not paying attention — kind of like if you were listening to someone singing in Simlish or that one song that’s meant to sound like English but isn’t. I won’t pretend to know how Google achieved these results, but it’s released a research paper explaining it in detail if you’re the type of person who would understand this figure:            A figure explaining the “hierarchical sequence- to-sequence modeling task” that the researchers use along with   AudioLM, another Google project  .

The site lets you play the input audio, where someone hums or whistles a tune, then lets you hear how the model reproduces it as an electronic synth lead, string quartet, guitar solo, etc. From the examples I listened to, it manages the task very well. Like with other forays into this type of AI, Google is being significantly more cautious with MusicLM than some of its peers may be with similar tech.
summaries.summary: Google researchers have developed MusicLM, an AI capable of generating minutes-long musical compositions from text prompts and transforming melodies whistled or hummed into various instruments. Unlike DALL-E's image creation, MusicLM focuses on music, producing songs based on detailed descriptions, including genre and instruments, and even simulating human vocals with a unique, albeit slightly grainy, quality. Demonstrations include genre-specific clips, instrumental transformations, and a "story mode" that shifts through musical themes. Despite its impressive capabilities, Google has no immediate plans to release MusicLM, citing concerns over potential misuse, such as plagiarism and cultural misappropriation. However, they are sharing a dataset of 5,500 music-text pairs to aid other researchers in musical AI development.

highlights: The problem is that the more AI is used in a story’s creation, the more chance there is for mistakes to be introduced. This is especially true of tools like ChatGPT, which have a tendency to produce “fluent bullshit” — that is, plausible but incorrect information. Recently, CNET was criticized for failing to clearly disclose its use of AI in writing a number of articles offering financial advice in its money section.

Automated tools are used to input figures and results into prewritten templates. As AI systems have improved, though, so has their ability to write more of a story. The problem is that the more AI is used in a story’s creation, the more chance there is for mistakes to be introduced.
summaries.summary: BuzzFeed announced plans to integrate AI tools from ChatGPT creator OpenAI to "enhance" and "personalize" its digital content, as revealed in a memo by CEO Jonah Peretti. This initiative, part of a broader strategy to adapt to digital media's future trends, aims to launch "AI inspired content" in 2023, focusing on quizzes, brainstorming, and content personalization. Despite the company's rocky financial journey post-IPO, this news prompted a significant share price surge. While AI's role in content creation grows, concerns about accuracy and "fluent bullshit" persist, highlighted by recent scrutiny over CNET's undisclosed AI use in financial advice articles. Peretti's vision emphasizes AI's potential to usher in a new era of creativity, complementing human ideas and cultural insights.

highlights: They claim it is significantly more efficient than previous image generators, creating images in a third of the time Stable Diffusion needs, and with higher quality results. Google's new technique can also be used to edit images using text instructions—something that could prove useful to creative professionals. One thing holding back wider use of image generators is that they do not have a meaningful understanding of how text relates to elements in an image.

One thing holding back wider use of image generators is that they do not have a meaningful understanding of how text relates to elements in an image. In October, two students at MIT, Nan Liu and Shuang Li, demonstrated a way to ask an image generator to include or exclude specific elements in an image, and specify details like placing one object in front of another. That could help people get image generators to do what they ask more often, but Josh Tenenbaum, a professor at MIT involved in the project, says the fact remains that existing AI tools simply do not understand the world in the way humans do.
summaries.summary: The proliferation of AI image generators has sparked widespread experimentation and debate over their implications, including potential biases, copyright issues, and the displacement of artists. Google's Muse, a new, more efficient image-generation tool, exemplifies the rapid advancements in this field, promising higher quality images and text-based editing capabilities. Meanwhile, MIT researchers have made strides in enabling more precise control over image content, though challenges in AI's understanding of complex descriptions persist. As AI art tools evolve, 2023 is expected to see improved AI-generated images and the advent of AI video generators, with companies like Google, Meta, and Nvidia at the forefront. This progress raises questions about the creative, ethical, and economic impacts of AI, suggesting a future of both enhanced creative possibilities and ongoing debates.

highlights: “And it works because this content doesn’t really need to function: It doesn’t have functionality constraints. Maybe you can replace them with deep-learning-based stuff. But I don’t think it’s going to make a big difference.
With computers doing the boring stuff, a small team could whip up a map the size of San Andreas. Crunch becomes a thing of the past; games release in a finished state. A new age beckons.
summaries.summary: The gaming industry's excitement about generative AI, seen as a solution to automate tedious tasks and potentially revolutionize game development, is met with skepticism and concerns about its practicality and impact on creativity. Critics argue the hype around AI in gaming mirrors past frenzies like crypto, with unrealistic expectations about AI replacing human artists. Despite claims from venture capital firms like Andreessen Horowitz about AI shortening development times and enhancing game design, industry professionals, including CD Projekt Red's Patrick Mills and NYU's Julian Togelius, highlight the technology's current limitations, particularly in level design and maintaining game integrity. Procedural generation, a non-AI technique already used in games, requires significant human oversight, suggesting that generative AI might not drastically change game development. Concerns also extend to the potential for AI to disrupt traditional game design and the creative process, with some developers and artists wary of AI's ability to replicate human creativity and the ethical implications of using AI-generated content. Despite these

highlights: Google may be only a year or two away from total disruption. AI will eliminate the Search Engine Result Page, which is where they make most of their money. Even if they catch up on AI, they can't fully deploy it without destroying the most valuable part of their business!

AI will eliminate the Search Engine Result Page, which is where they make most of their money. Even if they catch up on AI, they can't fully deploy it without destroying the most valuable part of their business! https://t.co/jtq25LXdkj
summaries.summary: Paul Buchheit, Gmail's creator, predicts Google's potential downfall within two years due to OpenAI's ChatGPT, suggesting AI could disrupt Google's main revenue source: the Search Engine Result Page. Launched in November 2022, ChatGPT's conversational response style contrasts with traditional search engines, prompting Google to refocus on AI. Google, with a 2021 revenue exceeding $250 billion, faces a crisis as users may prefer ChatGPT's simplicity. Microsoft's significant investment in ChatGPT aims to challenge Google's dominance. Despite ChatGPT's creators doubting its impact on Google, the collaboration with Microsoft indicates a shift towards AI-driven search solutions.

highlights: “Will it be interesting for an entirely virtual species to inhabit [virtual reality]? Maybe that could be cool, but that doesn’t help us. So even people thinking about uploading their consciousness — I’ve thought through that one a lot — it would be a copy of me, but it wouldn’t be me.”

… I’ll give an example of how deep it goes: it’s not just what you learned in college or what you learned in kindergarten; it’s even what you learned as a baby, as a toddler, like learning how to see, or learning how to walk. But what does it mean that I have to relearn how to see and walk? As virtual reality improves — and with all the talk of the metaverse and so forth, which we will  discuss later on — increasingly, it’s likely that [there] will be many more activities shifting from the physical biological world that we know into a new reality — a virtual reality — which has different physical and biological laws.
summaries.summary: Yuval Noah Harari, a historian and WEF adviser, discussed with podcaster Tom Bilyeu the potential need for humans to adapt fundamentally to a virtual reality future, suggesting that traditional human experiences like seeing and walking might have to be relearned. In a conversation published on Tuesday, Harari explored the idea that the evolution of virtual reality and concepts like the metaverse could shift human activities from the physical to a virtual realm, requiring a reevaluation of basic human skills and experiences. He emphasized the importance of mental flexibility in navigating the 21st century, highlighting the challenge of letting go of deeply ingrained learning, even as basic as walking or seeing, to adapt to new realities. Bilyeu raised concerns about the implications of divorcing humanity from its physical existence, questioning the feasibility and desirability of transferring human consciousness into a virtual domain.

highlights: The feature is designed to keep up with traffic, steer within a lane, and follow traffic signals, and despite the “full-self driving” name, it is required that human drivers be prepared to take control at any moment. Drivers are reportedly warned on an in-car screen by Tesla when installing the feature that it “may do the wrong thing at the worst time.” Tesla generally does not respond to request for comments, but said in an update to its vehicle safety data this month: “We are proud of Autopilot’s performance and its impact on reducing traffic collisions. The benefit and promise of Autopilot is clear from the Vehicle Safety Report data that we have been sharing for 4 years.”

Drivers are reportedly warned on an in-car screen by Tesla when installing the feature that it “may do the wrong thing at the worst time.” Tesla generally does not respond to request for comments, but said in an update to its vehicle safety data this month: “We are proud of Autopilot’s performance and its impact on reducing traffic collisions. The benefit and promise of Autopilot is clear from the Vehicle Safety Report data that we have been sharing for 4 years.”   Lucas Nolan is a reporter for Breitbart News covering issues of free speech and online censorship.
summaries.summary: On Thanksgiving Day, a Tesla Model S equipped with Elon Musk's Autopilot "full self-driving" software was involved in an eight-car pileup on the San Francisco Bay Bridge, injuring nine people, including a 2-year-old child. The crash occurred when the Tesla abruptly changed lanes and stopped, slowing to 7 mph. The driver reported that the vehicle's software braked unexpectedly, triggering the collision. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is investigating the incident, which happened hours after Musk announced the availability of the full self-driving system in North America. Despite its name, Tesla warns that the system may malfunction and requires driver readiness to take control.
